Among the convictione which belong to man, as a moral creature, is this; that not only his outward actions, but his inward purposes, volitions, affectione, de· sires and habits, ought to be right. This consideration, however, leads us into a region of morality with which Grotius is not much concerned in the present work.

Many of the questions of International Law which are discussed by Grotius, have been the subjectos much sub- sequent discussion; and in several cases, the opinions now generally accepted are different from those which he asserta. To have attempted to notice such cases, would have been, not to edit Grotius, but to compile a Treatise on the present state and past history of intemational Law. The student of such subjecte will necessarily have to read many books; of which, however, this of Grotius is cer- tainly one of the most indispensable. What is requisite ia order to correct him, must be obtained by studying the best of his successore.
